abstract: David W Dunlap Building Blocks column observes that crossroads of Greenwich and Fulton Streets in downtown Manhattan are set to open to public use for first time since 1967, when area was subsumed into the footprint of the original World Trade Center; notes space stands between several prominent sights, including the Oculus transportation hub and the front plaza of the National September 11th Memorial Museum.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, pedestrians will be able to reach the intersection of Greenwich and Fulton Streets, subsumed by the original World Trade Center in 1967, from the north, west and south.

headline.main: A Crossroads Decades Gone Will Reopen at the World Trade Center
headline.print_headline: A Crossroads Decades Gone Welcomes Back Pedestrians

snippet: On Thursday, pedestrians will be able to reach the intersection of Greenwich and Fulton Streets, subsumed by the original World Trade Center in 1967, from the north, west and south.

keywords.value: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
